H0.text: Rain is the point in the water cycle where radioactive contamination would most likely be found, since radioactive waste from nuclear power plants is sealed and deeply buried, reducing the chances that water will become contaminated.

H1.text: Fog is the point in the water cycle where radioactive contamination would most likely be found, given that radioactive waste from nuclear power plants is sealed in containers and deeply buried in the ground, reducing the chances that water will become contaminated.

H2.text: Groundwater is the point in the water cycle where radioactive contamination would most likely be found, because radioactive waste from nuclear power plants is sealed in containers and deeply buried, which reduces the chances that water will become contaminated.

H3.text: Surface water is the point in the water cycle where radioactive contamination would most likely be found from radioactive waste that has been sealed in containers and deeply buried in nuclear power plants, as sealing and burying reduces the chances that water will become contaminated.

A4.text: Radionuclides such as uranium (U) or radon (Rn) naturally present in some geological formations.

A5.text: Highly toxic waste that cannot be further recycled must be stored in isolation, to avoid contamination of air, ground and underground water.

A6.text: Natural uranium ore deposits serve as proof of concept for stability of radioactive elements in geological formations—Cigar Lake Mine for example is a natural deposit of highly concentrated uranium ore located under sandstone and a quartz layer at a depth of 450 m, that is 1 billion years old with no radioactive leaks to the surface.

A7.text: In Italy, several radioactive waste deposits let material flow into river water, thus contaminating water for domestic use.

A8.text: In the Soviet Union, waste stored in Lake Karachay was blown over the area during a dust storm after the lake had partly dried out.

A10.text: Groundwater can spend over 10,000 years beneath Earth's surface before leaving.

A11.text: The oceans hold 97% of the total water on the planet; 78% of global precipitation occurs over the ocean, and it is the source of 86% of global evaporation.

A12.text: In France in the summer of 2008, at the Areva plant in Tricastin, liquid containing untreated uranium overflowed out of a faulty tank, about 75 kg of the radioactive material seeped into the ground and, from there, into two rivers nearby.

A13.text: Scavenging of abandoned radioactive material has been the cause of several other cases of radiation exposure, mostly in developing nations, which may have less regulation of dangerous substances and a market for scavenged goods and scrap metal.
